item.title: "Explore" the Myntra knowledge graph
item.description:
Introduction

Routinely there are multitudes of questions that one like to get answers to, to first understand how people interact with Myntra.com and then optimise their store experience. These questions come in different variety and from different functions in the organisation, ranging from store managers to merchandisers to business analysts wherein each of them are looking at data with a different perspective altogether. Case in point being merchandisers looking to understand how their brands fared and store managers looking to understand which store fronts did well and which needs attention.

Solution Design

The questions that are routinely asked for are on the following line

  • how many eyeballs a particular brand got and from where
  • which storefronts are the ones which are leading to more views and conversion
  • where is the brand and article types getting sold from
  • what gets sold from a storefront
  • which pages do the most profitable customers go on the website
  • how do people interact with top-navigation pages
  • what gets used along with brand filter of a particular brand

and potentially many more. Possibly infinite.

One way to solve this is to act reactively and try to write jobs which compute answers to these specific questions individually and then made available in some database table or through some static report. Downside of this approach being loss of agility (development takes time!!) and effort required to look at multiple reports and making sense of it.

The approach being proposed here is to create a knowledge graph which would represent all major interactions happening on Myntra.com.

The three fundamental entities in the knowledge graph are
1. The nodes in the graph. Some sample nodes are listed below

  • Brand nodes - Nike, Puma, Roadster etc.
  • Filter nodes - Size 8, Size 9, Fabric Cotton etc.
  • Navigation Page nodes - men casual shoes, men tees polos, etc.
  • Banner nodes - Wrogn, Anouk, etc.

2. The edges are the connections between these nodes. For instance some potential nodes to which "Roadster" node in the graph would be connected to could be

  • Navigation page nodes - men casual shoes, men sports shoes
  • Filter nodes - size 8, size 9
  • Content - roadster shop in shop
  • Consumer - high margin customers

3. The data on the node itself. Some potential data points that can exist on "Roadster" brand node

  • Popular storefronts Roadster is discovered from
  • Popular article type visibility of Roadster
  • Discount visibility of Roadster
  • Popular user searches to discover Roadster
  • Filters used with Roadster
  • Top pages Roadster is sold from

Usage

The knowledge graph once created can then be exposed through an UI where users can search for nodes of interest (say brand Roadster or Casual Shoes article type) and see the data/details present on the node. The next step can be to hop on to any of the next linked node to continue on the data discovery journey.


Implementation

The system is called "Explore" which essentially computes hundreds of thousands of interesting aggregates daily, creates the graph structure and exposes it through an easily navigable UI.

Happy "Explore"ing...
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Divya Alok)

item.title: Last of the Best - Clearing off broken sizes
item.description:
Problem at hand

Online retailers are often stuck with a long tail of low stocked products. The problem is compounded with their discovery deliberately made harder due to unavailability of majority size options. This leads to forced liquidation of these products at high discount levels leading to high losses on these. Many a times these are best selling merchandise which moved faster than the others and are left in a low inventory situation.

Solution design

Since many these products have been best sellers there are high chances of them moving without significant discounts leading to better margins. The trick being not to promote these through the main website properties where we run the risk of exposing broken sizes leading to disappointed visitors with a negative perception that the retailer is not well stocked. One solution we are trying out is to create a separate property ("last of the best" campaign) which brings together these products and create focused visibility around it.

To create a focused visibility, we are trying out to use the sizing data we have for our customers (based on the browsing footprints that a customer leaves with us). When we marry this data with the best seller campaign property, we get a fairly compelling proposition.

Here is how it works, a mechanism like Sense finds out visitor's interest in real-time and beams a "last of the best" campaign story focusing on the detected article type with size filters auto-applied. e.g.  a customer detected looking for T-Shirts and the tee size identified as M, is directed to the best seller T-Shirts page with products stocked in at least size M.

This approach on one hand helps a customer get an easy access to the best sellers in his/her size without too much effort. On the other hand, limited availability creates that needed urgency to move the product.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Divya Alok)

item.title: Personalised Navigation
item.description:
With multiple mobile devices becoming an important part of almost every Indian household, the future of m-commerce increasingly seems certain. The relatively smaller screens and lesser properties available on mobiles as compared to traditional laptops or PCs present an interesting opportunity to simplify how users discover different products.

One popular method to simplify product discovery is product recommendation. Such a technique works well when users have a rough idea of what they want to buy. Unfortunately in fashion, this is not the case for many users. For example, a user may casually browse through a few T-Shirts and one shoe. In such cases, the intent is not very specific as the user is simply browsing through different categories or collections to see if he or she likes something. If we use traditional recommendation techniques, the algorithm may recommend similar shoes to the user as it was the last seen item. However, looking at his series of clicks, it clearly useful to show him both T-shirts and shoes.

To overcome this challenge, we need a slightly different approach to personalisation. Instead of looking at each item in isolation, we need to look at the complete journey or navigation of the user. Personalised Navigation is an extension of the User Journey Model (UJM), which aims to pre-empt navigation to the user by taking into account his browsing context. We have seen how user intent can be captured from clickstream data using the UJM. Now, lets say we continuously capture the user's clickstream near real time and calculate his or her intent every few minutes. As the users browse, our algorithm can dynamically adapt to their intent and refresh the suggested products near real time.

Importantly, with Personalised Navigation the user will be able to find the products of his interest with minimum clicks, as our algorithm keeps predicting the next best products to present to the user.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Ashay Tamhane)

item.title: Oculus - Real Time Business Insights
item.description:
There's a growing need for modern businesses to react faster to events happening inside their business. For online retailers where the store experience can be changed on the fly, it becomes all the more important to have a hold of critical information in real-time. Traditionally analytics have been either based on web analytics tools such as GA, Omniture, etc. or in-house transactional systems which manage orders, customers, inventory, etc. These systems beyond a point not help in getting a visibility of a lot of important business metrics. For instance, understanding gender based browsing patterns, page/storefront performance, storefront wise discount leakage, visibility of revenue earned till now, revenue projection, traffic distribution, etc. Each one of these if measured during the day, can help build deep understanding of business as it happens and leads to a more informed business decision towards maximising various goals. Some practical examples can be, reduction of discounts on a page where there is more leakage or promoting pages where discounts have been put and is short of traffic, what time of the day to put discounts on women's products, who are the people on the website right now and creating interesting propositions, etc. Our solution to these problems is "Oculus" which is a real time analytics engine aggregating visits on the website and delivering meaningful business insights right when it is required.

Case in point are the below charts from Oculus that help understand the demand of categories and brands trending right now.




Business at the speed of thought! Who says it can't be done.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Monish Kaul)

item.title: Understanding visibility as a key driver ...
item.description:
While we continuously work on decoding high-intent traffic at myntra, it is equally imperative that we understand key drivers of conversion: price, visibility, portal experience, etc.. We have had multiple posts around visibility but today I wanted to take a stab at exploring some theoretical constructs in an attempt to better understand it. Brace yourself for a verbose post !!

Let me set up the context by comparing our 2 primary levers - price and visibility. Price as a key driver has been well studied in retail and we have a fair understanding of key constructs around pricing - price elasticities, price response curves and Willingness-To-Pay (WTP). The underlying connections for parametric distributions have also been drawn out; For e,g, constant elasticity is derived via a log-linear price response curve which is further hinged on an underlying exponential WTP distribution. In a highly discounted landscape, where customers are in some sense discount spoilt, an exponential WTP could be a reasonable assumption rather than a bell-curve WTP. At myntra, we are exploring with different price response curves on our historical data. Note that elasticity is just one of the levers towards price optimisation; Fine grained understanding and execution of all levers towards optimal and profitable pricing is a challenging task.

Compared to price, visibility has been less studied. Although offline brick and mortar stores are exposed to visibility as a lever and have leveraged it to tactically arrange styles at display, the underlying problem of product discovery which visibility is trying to solve is significantly less pronounced there as compared to an online store; Ratio of limited real estate versus the infinite breadth in products on an online portal is overwhelming and renders discoverability extremely challenging. While personalisation is the right approach to manage this ratio, we will still need to optimally allocate visibility. 

Visibility Response Curves and Visibility Elasticity

Visibility optimisation can be potentially approached in similar ways as price optimisation but with some caveats. To keep the discussion more focused, we will restrict the visibility problem to the list page property and the rank ordering of styles within a list page. As a first step, using historical data around the number of list views a product received and its corresponding sales, the visibility response curve and visibility elasticity - the % shift in demand of a product due to % shift in its visibility - can be estimated. The visibility response curve specifies the demand of a product as a function of the visibility offered to the product. As visibility decreases, demand declines;  At an extreme level if we de-list a product we definitely won’t realise any sales for it. On the other end, as visibility achieves saturation, the lift in demand is marginal. So far, this has been a straightforward extension of price response curves.

Consumer Behaviour Implications: Search vs Discovery

Just like in the case of price response curves, can we say something about the implications of different shapes of the visibility response curve on the consumer behaviour? Assume we tactically reduce the visibility of a specific product or a collection, the consumer will now have to search a bit more if he needs to uncover this product. This brings out the fundamental difference between search and discovery. Search implies consumer has a fair idea of what he is looking for while the objective of discovery is to present product propositions to the consumer which he/she is not aware of yet would inspire him to buy. Lets take an example: if a person wants to buy a "Nike" running shoes, he has a fair idea of his want and does not need explicit marketing assistance from us. However, if someone is looking for running shoes in general and is not sure of the specific product, the salesmans' duty is to present to him the right product at the right price inducing a high chance of conversion. 

This implies that, unlike price response curve, the visibility response curve is hinged on a mixture of a) the distribution of customers’ having a clear knowledge of the product they want to buy plus an appetite to search and b) the distribution of consumers’ needing some assistance in discovering the product. Reducing visibility therefore implies that demand might dip because the product needs to now surface through a focused search and fewer customers of type (b) will now discover it. It will be interesting to see how varying parametric shapes around these distributions and different mixture functions affect the visibility response curve shapes.

Cannibalisation

Unlike price, where similar products need not compete for promotions budget, visibility has a strong cannibalisation feature built into to it. Given that only a limited number of products can show up on the list page, cannibalisation is imperative. Hence cross-elasticity - the % shift in demand of a product A due to % shift in visibility of a similar product B - is a must have when modelling for visibility response curves.

Visibility Optimisation


Finally, the visibility strategy needs to optimise for multiple factors beyond elasticity. One could ask for a greedy approach of giving more visibility to products which have high elasticity arguing that they need it more. However, such a myopic strategy could significantly hurt us. Ultimately, we are only successful if a consumer finds a great product at a great price and buys it and returns to buy more. An accurate approach calls for a robust list - page optimisation formulation where we optimise the overall property for net conversion rate among the candidates which are relevant to the user query.  

As we embark on analysing visibility as a key driver, I am hoping the above constructs come in handy.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Deepak Warrier)

item.title: User Journey Model and its Application
item.description:
Every day, thousands of users browse through fashionable products on Myntra. Users might visit Myntra directly, or through other channels such as internet search, mailers or social media. Once they land on the website or mobile app, they typically browse through several products before making a purchase. Understanding users' journey as they find a product of interest is therefore complicated, but important.

We at Myntra, are building a predictive model to understand user journeys. This 'User Journey Model' is built by learning browsing patterns from millions of historical samples, using a Hidden Markov Model (HMM). The model can predict a user's journey, given his or her recent browsing history. Such a model can be helpful in several use cases including digital marketing, personalised navigation, and personalised search. As a sample use case of the User Journey Model, let's see how it can help us in digital marketing.

Dynamic User Segments for Digital Marketing

"Whom to target, and when?" is an important question to ask while targeting users for digital marketing.  Often, the strategy is to identify users at the end of the conversion funnel. We can think of this funnel as a user's journey through Myntra as s/he decides to buy a product. In other words, the more a user is towards the end of the conversion funnel, the higher is his or her intent to buy. For example, a user may not have purchased a product yet, however he or she may have added it to cart. It is a good idea to target such users, as they are towards the end of the funnel and therefore show high intent. We can create a user segment with the rule: 'include all users who have added a product to cart, but have not bought it'. Similarly, we can create several other rules to identify high intent users.

However, such event based rules allow us to detect only a limited set of high intent users. For example, a large number of users may like a certain product, but may not explicitly add it to cart or wish list. In this case, we may lose a big chunk of high intent users who could be potential buyers. Moreover, as many of the segments are more or less static (ex: registered but not bought), the same users tend to get bombarded with repeated emails. This can lead to low mail open rates and even unsubscribes.

The User Journey Model can help us fill in such gaps. It can look at the recent browsing pattern of a user, and determine his or her intent. In other words, it tries to guess if a user is really interested in buying a product, even if he or she hasn't explicitly clicked on say, 'add to cart'. We can now dynamically create a segment of high intent users, in addition to segments created via event based rules. In case of mailers and SMS based campaigns, we can control the number of communications to send depending on users' level of intent. Essentially, we can target a user only when he shows high level of intent.

Let us take a real example of determining intent of an individual user. Ashish is browsing for products in the following order:


He first looked at a Navy Blue Hooded Sweatshirt. However, later he started browsing for Jeans. The sports sandal towards the end could be a seen as a diversion from his intent. Such diversions are fairly common while browsing. This is exactly why, looking at the complete sequence is very important to identify the likely intent of the user, as it gives the necessary context.

Given such a sequence of browsing, our algorithm can answer a couple of questions. First, what is the intent level of Ashish? Second, what are the exact products that he seems to show intent in.


The User Journey Model answers in terms of a 'product group' or a group of similar products. Shown above is one of the product groups (Faded Jeans) which Ashish seems to show intent in, as determined by our algorithm. It also determines the level of intent he shows in this particular product group. We can now target Ashish, and other similar users in a campaign for 'Faded Jeans'. This is how we can dynamically form high intent user segments which are specific to product groups. Also, such information could be useful for re-marketing products to high intent users.

Creating Intent Based Campaigns
Since we have intent levels for all users, we can now aggregate them at the channel level across different product categories. The two heat maps below show how users' intent is spread across different product categories for every channel. The first heat map is for women's product categories, while the second one is for men. Simply put, we compare the shades in each row (darker shade implies more intent). As the users' intent changes, the intent seen across product categories and product groups also changes. Currently, we calculate intent on a daily basis. We can therefore create campaigns for the product categories showing high intent on a given day.




For example, in the above heat maps, let us consider the Partnership channel. Among men categories, Sweatshirts and Sweaters seem to have higher user intent on the given day. Similarly, among women categories, we notice that Jackets and Shorts have higher user intent. Such information could be used along with recent campaign details to make a decision on which campaigns should be created or continued.

To conclude, we believe that User Journey Model is a powerful tool and can help us in various use cases. We plan to launch intent based campaigns for digital marketing shortly.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Ashay Tamhane)

item.title: Visibility Part 3 - Contextual Visibility
item.description:
This is the third part of the series of articles on visibility. The previous articles being - Visibility-Product Ranking and Visibility-Multi Storefronts. While the previous articles talk about the general ranking algorithms and maintaining multiple stores, the subject of the current article is around contextual visibility.

Why contextual?

The general product ranking algorithm is majorly influenced by what the larger customer base or audience is doing on the website. In a nut shell, most of the product listing is derived from the wisdom of the crowd or the inherent demand signals at a store level. On the other hand extreme personalisation talks about knowing the customer well and then customising the store experience. All these approaches miss the current context of an individual which when used can augment the store experience significantly. e.g. A man looking for trousers in the chilly winters can be communicated with woollen trousers' collection; based on the body type and occasion, the proposition can be further enhanced to have choice of fit - a slim or a regular fit as well.

Why is it necessary?

On one hand this approach help user's to explore unique concepts present in the store relevant to the current context, as well help get focussed and relevant attention to products which otherwise get hidden in the wide choices that we offer. Version 1 take on this approach has been implemented by Sense.

How is "the context" derived?

Context is derived by crunching a lot of signals we have accumulated over time for a user, e.g. the devices being used, the channels to access the store, the products selected and clicked, the products added to cart, usage of search, choice of filters, brands seen, etc.

Is it real-time?

Yes. We have the context engine running 24X7 establishing context for millions of visits that we get everyday and is triggered as soon as someone starts interacting with the store.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Divya Alok)

item.title: Understanding Price Elasticity
item.description:
Discounts, coupons, deals, offers, etc. are the ways retailers have been attracting hordes of consumers ever since. E-tailers, the much recent entrants in the retail business, however, have taken these offerings to the next level owing to many game changing factors at their disposal - leveraging on advantages arising out of fundamentally different ways they conduct the retail business. As the reach of these offerings is quite broad in the online e-tail domain, we need to carefully understand the impact of discounting on the overall sales and revenue.

We at data science team in Myntra are looking at sales patterns to build intelligent and data driven strategies towards pricing. It is known that demand for a good varies with its pricing, “elasticity” helps us understand this variation. Hence, as a first step, modeling the price elasticity of demand for our products would give us better understanding of our catalogue from a pricing perspective and provide a rich framework for pricing projects such as: portfolio optimisation, simulation experiments in pricing, dynamic adaptive pricing, etc.


What is Elasticity?

Elasticity is defined as the ratio of percentage change in the quantity sold to percentage change in price. E.g. If 5% drop in prices for a style brings 10% increase in the number of styles sold, the elasticity for that style would be -2, the negative sign signifying that the direction of change sales is opposite to the direction of change in prices. In this sense, +ve elasticity value for a style means that increasing discount on such styles would lead to a reduction in its sales. Though this needs to be taken with a pinch of salt, we can certainly understand that highly discounting such products may not yield the desired lift in their sales.

For example consider a few categories shown in the below figure, where the size of the bubble represents their absolute elasticity values. Categories on the left, where models yielded positive elasticity, have peculiar characteristics: they cater to users’ aspirational needs (e.g. ring); would have sold anyways (e.g. dupatta, ties) or these seem to be products where users don’t want to go wrong in their purchase and hence don’t rely on discount based purchase (e.g. inner wear). There could be deeper interpretations to why elasticity of some products turns out to be positive or relatively less elastic (greater than -1.0).
 
Similarly, on the right, we can see that categories like watches, t-shirts, shoes, etc. are quite elastic (i.e. elasticity values lesser than -1) which means, the sales for such categories is quite driven by their discounting levels.
 
However note that, at a broad category level, as discussed above, these insights can provide only broad guidelines, and for more actionable insights we need to build models at a much granular level.
  
Granular modeling of elasticity for actionable insights

For actionable insights from elasticity models we would like to know how different styles within a category behave at different pricing levels. For this we need to build elasticity models for specific groups of styles. Determining this group of products for which we can assume same elasticity, and study them together, is tricky. A particular style can’t be siloed, and studied for its elasticity, completely independent of other styles, which are very similar to it. We also run into risk of data sparsity at a very fine grain level view for studying elasticity of products and may miss out on a possibly emerging pattern had we taken a coarser look. To do this wisely we leverage on how users perceived the set of styles to which they were exposed to, and use their crowd curated ‘collection’ of styles perceived as similar on multitude of attributes such as brand, article, styling, colour, etc. These collections could be roughly imagined as aisles in a store. Sometimes looking at these aisles suffices to study price elasticity and sometimes we need to resort to the ‘racks’ within these aisles and study elasticity for group of neighborhood styles placed on those racks when the aisle as a whole can’t provide a coherent picture w.r.t elasticity. In the below figure, we can see how granular models for Kook N Keech Disney have different behaviors w.r.t elasticity. It is typically observed that higher price band KnK Disney styles have positive elasticity. This fact, coupled with the observation in http://sartorialscience.myntrablogs.com/2014/11/understanding-brand-positioning.html, that KnK Disney is a low entropy brand, could indicate that there may be a interest group for KnK Disney who are not just driven by discounts but are interested in the unique offering such styles have to provide and don’t care only about discounts while making their purchase decision. On the other hand, collections of brand Eavan, stay consistent in their elasticity value when modeled at more granular sub-collection level.

Elasticity modeling at different levels of granularity


How are these models built?

There are quite a few challenges in modeling elasticity, as there are many factors which together control the sales happening at a point of time. We need to control for these factors while studying elasticity. Some of these factors are:
•  Momentum: a trend in sales is observed for certain article types which needs to be factored e.g. Jackets show a trend during winters
•   Day of Week Factor: for certain articles day of week seems to play a role
•   Traffic Volatility: Marketing and other visibility factors govern the amount of traffic that a style begets, which in-turn affects its sales; we need to control for such factors while studying price elasticity.

There are many applications and also many pertinent observations that arise out of such elasticity modeling; we would discuss these in the forth-coming articles.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Prasad Joshi)

item.title: Dynamic Bot Detection Using Bloom Filters
item.description:
Problem at hand

Bots or crawl programs are a fact of life for any property accessible on the web, be it a blog, an e-commerce website, a media website or a company website. There may be varied crawling motives ranging from search engines to competitors to internal test suites to rookie programmers. These bots can be either classified as "good bots" who explicitly announce their visit and there are "not so good bots" who choose to mask themselves. These category of "not so good bots" meddle up with the analytics tasks at hand because of them getting wrongly categorised as genuine users.

Any pattern to leverage?

Bots are usually in a hurry to crawl the website and issue page requests at a far higher frequency than humanly possible. This property can be effectively leveraged to find whether the website activity is done by a bot or a human.

Solution design - bloom filters

Bloom filters are an efficient way to find rapidly and memory-efficiently, whether an element is present in a set. The solution design is simply around maintaining a bloom filter for every second of the day and putting the web request signature (request ip address + request user agent) into it for every incoming web request. After putting this entry, check for the same signature's existence in the last 60 seconds buckets, which is an efficient task and can be done in real-time for all incoming requests due to the speed guarantees that bloom filter provides. In case this is a bot there would be very high chances of finding the same signature in majority of the past 60 buckets. We can now choose a policy of counting such "offences" and put a threshold above which the signature would be blacklisted and all related activities filtered.


Results

We have been able to find and classify around 5% of total events received as bots which would have otherwise sneaked in.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Divya Alok)

item.title: Decoding fashion styling and beyond...
item.description:
We know what people purchase and also what they browse. But we don’t know what they wear.

It’s likely that apart from the customer, anyone would struggle in answering this question. This obviously includes us. No wonder ‘people who bought this also bought’ sections on prominent apparel retailer sites are often contextually irrelevant when it comes to cross-selling of products. How often do we see a footwear being recommended with a selected trouser making a sensible match?

So, here’s how we think of unclogging this problem:
1) Understanding and codifying the principles behind fashion styling
2) Using them for styling
3) Keep refining and discovering more of them


As depicted above, this has to be a highly iterative process of discovery, application and refinement. So lets take off the ground by addressing the elephant in the room - what are the principles of fashion styling?

Principles of fashion styling
All of us would agree that there have to be a set of implicit rules or patterns at work which the stylists apply before advising their clients to spruce up. This knack of making over someone’s appearance cannot be totally arbitrary. It is evident that choosing cuts and fabric, combining colours, accessorising and a whole gamut of other styling tricks are based on certain solid principles or rules(of thumb). The stylists then of course creatively improvise and customise these principles for catering to client requirements. This said, we now want to build an automated web-scale solution - for which we definitely need these ‘rules’.So, how do we enable such a discovery?

Lets consider one of the facets of styling - accessorising. For suggesting appropriate accessories, one needs to know which piece gels with which outfit, say for an occasion. Is it possible to ask our stylists to enlist ‘rules’ underlying accessorising? Now, there are few problems crippling this approach - will it capture myriad combinations (read combinatorial explosion) possible?; given that trends are dynamic by nature and multiple such facets to be covered, how feasible is it to do such an exercise often? Not to mention the possibility of various biases creeping in due to lack of diverse opinion.

Illustration of some styling rules discovered from Myntra MY STYLIST outfits
If directly tapping styling knowledge is challenging, we can mine stylist data to unearth some implicit rules. As an illustration, we have taken 900+ MY STYLIST outfits(as of this writing), filtered on the female gender and derived the following insights. It is not an exhaustive rules list by any measure but it opens up possibilities.

1) Category pairing rules

The figure below depicts the proportional co-occurrence of different accessories with dresses, kurtas and tops respectively. It serves as a guide on accesorizing for these categories. For instance we notice that clutches tag well with dresses whereas for tops handbags seem the best sell. Similarly, kurtas and legging seem wonder match whereas with tops skirts/jeans/trousers go great.


2) Attributes pairing rules

This illustration is a deep dive into various attributes of earrings. Drilling down the earring types for dresses, kurtas and tops, it emerges that drop earrings pair well with kurtas whereas stud earrings seem more popular with tops and dresses. 


3) Deducing colour combinations

In this segment, we will interpret how colour combinations interplay towards pairing of tops and trousers. Looking at black, burgundy, red and white tops we can make out which trouser colour strike along best.


Web-data, wisdom of crowds and gamification
These illustrations point out how the output from a handful of stylists can be useful in obtaining some of the principles behind fashion styling . We therefore must do the following to improve on our baseline:

1) Spread out further on the web to as many sources as possible for collecting rich styling data viz. look-books, content, outfits and so on. Yes, these sources could be social fashion engines like ASOS fashion-finder, Polyvore, Chicismo; intelligence providers like Editd, Wsgn and web APIs of Pinterest, Wanelo etc. 

2) Other key area to be focused at would be having an ongoing stream of user generated fashion content via some sort of gamification. Moreover, when we want to understand and profile the myriad fashion tastes of customers, collective judgement of large group of people will definitely be more accurate than the judgement of a handful of experts. As proved by some social fashion engines, this area is hot iron for applying wisdom of crowds. Internally, we noticed that pooled browsing behaviour of millions of site visitors gave us a nuanced understanding of merchandise similarity - which would be impossible when relying solely on product attributes. The similarity data powers most of the existing and upcoming personalisation features on the site.



It comes across that an approach thriving on extensive amounts of fashion data would be enormously effective. We’re experimenting with ASOS outfits data to have a data mashup on fashion styling. 

Personalised Outfit Suggestion Engine(POSE)
Above library/repository of styling rules derived in the form of discrete probability distributions can be principally combined together using bayesian reasoning and machine learning tools for a variety of problems. An interesting application would be to come up with a personalised outfit suggestion engine(POSE)  as opposed to regular cross-selling. The POSE comes to cater to the unique merchandise preferences of a customer. Leveraging on product level affinities from interaction data(browse & purchases) and the evolving knowledge base on fashion styling, will enable us to deliver this solution. We’ll talk more about POSE in the subsequent posts. 

Eventually a knowledge base on Indian fashion
Myntra platform is uniquely positioned to amass a wealth of data on Indian fashion and styling preferences. We posses detailed knowledge of product attributes on a vast catalogue. To boot that up, we have browsing, search and transactions data from millions of people.
We are planning to enable the insights, derived from our platform, openly accessible to the various players in the apparel ecosystem viz. manufacturers, designers, private boutiques/labels, fashion incubators, bloggers, content aggregators. Myntra will establish such social capital and thereby benefit from its consequential network effects. Further, this democratisation of knowledge has tremendous potential to level the playing field between fashion experts and non-experts in this industry. This in turn will throw the gates open for everyone to innovate, design and put up their stuff. We sketch a parallel here with the publishing industry which revolutionised with the ushering in of blogging platforms. 

We welcome more thoughts on this. So lets keep the chat on.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Devashish Mittal)

item.title: Every customer gets his own aisle: Hyper-Personalization
item.description:
Let me start with a ridiculous question. How is buying fashion different from buying train tickets? Well, today you can buy both online – isn’t it? Indeed. But, wonder why fashion e-tailing lagged behind online ticketing systems by more than a decade? Think what’s different in the offline scenarios. Remember those long queues at train ticket counters – thank lord they are a thing of the past! One computer can easily serve more people than a thousand ticket counters. A couple of quick questions are all that you need to answer to get a ticket. Thus, ticketing is a natural problem to service online. Contrast this with your experience at your favorite fashion outlet. You don’t need to beat long queues to get into the store but the salesperson asks you a hundred questions before (s)he can get you the product that you need. Smarter salespeople ask lesser questions. Instead, they keep scanning you – your reaction to products that you see, the stuff that you are currently wearing, the expensive mobile phone that you are carrying … every bit is crucial to pick that perfect product for you. Effective fashion e-tailing requires technology to match what goes on in the mind of the brightest of sales-reps, i.e., understand the personal style of the customer and throw up products that suit his/her taste.


Every customer is different – every customer is different everyday


What’s your personal style? Here are some interesting quotes (Read more):

“My personal style is a mixture of, like, girly, throwback, like retro '50s pin-ups, floral, like hippies, like anything feminine, and like flirty.”
Ariana Grande

“Personal style is not something that is just in the air. It is something you have and that you apply to yourself.”
Paloma Picasso

“My personal style has seen so many highs and lows. Probably more lows than highs.”
Josh Hutcherson

“Everyone looks at your watch and it represents who you are, your values and your personal style.”
Kobe Bryant

And here we are, claiming that technology can discover the personal style of every customer! (God save us :-))

In the last few months, we have taken the first steps toward understanding our customers’ style preferences and have started to personalize different touch-points related to product discovery and digital marketing. In this post, I share some examples of how we are personalizing product listings for regular shoppers at Myntra.

 

Personalizing Product Listings


Product listings in an e-commerce store are equivalent to aisles in a brick and mortar store. In fashion retail, organizing aisles and product racks is especially important since product discovery always starts there. You probably decide the model of the mobile phone that you purchase even before you walk into a store but you discover your t-shirts only while browsing through product racks. At Myntra, we focus a lot of our attention on product listings to ensure that the products that have the best chance of selling are featured at the top slots. At the same time, we give a fair chance to new products so that they can turn into best sellers.

A personalized product listing is a ranking of products generated for a customer that takes the following factors into consideration:
  • Personal Style / Product Taste: We profile everything that the customer browses or purchases in order to estimate his/her preferences toward different product attributes (e.g., brand, pattern, fabric, color, price points).
  • Current Intent: What is it that the customer looking for today?
  • Product Popularity: A product that sells more is likely to be ranked higher. In particular, we assess whether others who have a similar taste as that of the customer like the product.

Enough said. Lets look at some examples of how product pages at Myntra shape up differently for two of our customers – Devarshi and Anand. Clothes reveal one’s personality – see if you can know something about them by reading into their product listings!

Here are the top 8 products that Devarshi sees on the page for Men’s Sports Shoes at Myntra.

Nike - Rs 3995

Nike - Rs 2295

Adidas - Rs 4999

Puma - Rs 2299

Puma - Rs 4499

Adidas - Rs 3799

Puma - Rs 2999

Nike - Rs 7995


And, here are top 8 t-shirts that we pick for him.



Nike - Rs 3595

HRX - Rs 599

Roadster - Rs 399

Nike - Rs 2695

ETC - Rs 849

Nike - Rs 1295

Nike - Rs 1095

Nike - Rs 1595


Do you notice anything unusual? Compare these with what you see on these pages: Men’s Sports Shoes and Men’s T-shirts. Notice that 4 out of the 8 shoes are Football Shoes with cleats. Also, most of the t-shirts are football jerseys and active-wear. Devarshi definitely seems to be a sporty person, possibly into football. At least, so we believe!

Now, lets look at what we select for Anand. Here are the top 8 sports shoe picks for him.

Sparx - Rs 1375

Nike - Rs 3695

Nike - Rs 5495

HRX - Rs 2099

Sparx - Rs 1875

HRX - Rs 1999

Sparx - Rs 1499

Adidas - Rs 4999

Observe that the selection is biased toward the starting price range of sports shoes at Myntra. 4 out of the 8 products are priced under Rs 2000, others are mostly top sellers. This is because we perceive Anand as price sensitive; someone who really appreciates value for money. A similar trend is reflected in our selection for t-shirts for him (see below). We have picked some t-shirt packs and other best-sellers in our range of affordable tees.


Roadster - Rs 399

Roadster - Rs 799

Nike - Rs 1295

HIGHLANDER - Rs 899

Fort Collins - Rs 550

ETC - Rs 849

Roadster - Rs 849

HRX - Rs 799

Personalization is an area ripe with many interesting technological and research challenges. The Myntra team is fully committed toward solving these – we want no customer to ever complain that e-commerce lacks a personal touch! Stay tuned for future posts on different personalization initiatives at Myntra.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Debdoot Mukherjee)

item.title: Visibility Part 2 - Multi storefronts
item.description:
This is the second part of the series of articles on visibility. The first one being Visibility Part 1 - Product Ranking.

What's lacking in the current approach?

In the first article it was discussed as to how visibility is affected, measurement metrics, relation with product ranking and general considerations of the product ranking algorithm. The solution discussed revolved around establishing the relative importance of one product over the other (point in time) ultimately translating into one of the many possible configuration of an aisle or storefront. In the current scheme, only a small number of products get visibility over and over again leaving a large chunk of products with limited visibility and hence lower sales. The problem of "the lack of visibility" to a long tail of products is not addressed by this mechanism which is what we tried to address with the multi-storefront approach.

The concept

Multi-store is an aisle organisation mechanism to portray a wider width on the listing pages. This helps in out-of-turn promotion of products leading to better visibility distribution across products and overall better sales mix. The multi-store aisle organisation is achieved by identifying potential best-sellers amongst the low visible products and then infusing them with the regular "product ranked order" products. On the website this translates to different visitors getting different aisle or storefront organisations at the same time.


               

Note that two visitors getting exposed to two different storefronts of men casual shirts at the same time instance.

Results

The multi-store concept has been extended to more than two stores and has been in production for more than a year now. The following benefits have been observed
1. a better sales mix
2. newly introduced styles getting default visibility
3. enables extra aisle space to cater to changing business needs
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Divya Alok)

item.title: Sense(able) interventions
item.description:
Introduction

As an avid users of various fashion e-commerce platforms ourselves, at times we miss quality human interventions which can inform about the latest fashionable trends, stop us from making obvious fashion bloopers and offer help in choosing the right fit, colour, size, etc. The most obvious source of information today is the print media in the form of fashion magazines or fashion blogs maintained by individuals/companies. These rich sources of specialised fashion content can be at times overwhelming and takes quite some time on part of the user to absorb. Another difficulty lies in the access to this information (right information at the right time) while the purchase decisions are being made.

Enter the "Sense" world

What if we change the equation and approach the problem in a different way? Rather than overloading the user with fashion content upfront and pray the user goes through it, we understand the user first, understand what he/her is looking for (derive the context) and then have a more meaningful conversation around the fit, trending fashion, colour selection, etc. This is what "Sense" is all about. Crisply, it is a real-time processing engine which senses the presence of a user on the website, figures out all the past and current web interactions and tries to derive a context. The context has two faces, the first being "the short term intent" which explains what a user is interested in right now and the "long term taste and profile" which defines what a user likes in general. There are tons of user signals we use to derive the context, some of which are, the channel used to approach the website, landing pages, product pages, user searches, banner clicks, etc.

How can we use this?

There are broadly two ways we can use the derived context in general by
(a) having a more meaningful contextual conversation with the user based on the his tastes, likings and h(is|er) current interest.
(b) subtly changing the website to mould itself around the users' current interests.

The current state

The system is up and running for all desktop users right now. An example of "Sense" in action would be, if a user is looking for formal shirts there are high chances that we would be pushing a website notification informing the user about "magnetic button-down shirts" which is essentially a limited edition Invictus shirt collection having magnets to hold the collar down instead of buttons. The notification would look something like this and upon click would lead to the magnetic buttoned-down products by Invictus.




How does it help our customers and us?

On one hand, our customers benefit by getting introduced to unique product concepts and their crisp introduction without too much of self-motived content exploration. Also the communication being context aware (since it is real-time and based on their likings, preferences and short term intent) helps boost the shopping experience in a major way. On the other hand, the button-down collection gets focused visibility by formal shirt buyers and communicates the uniqueness in the collection crisply thereby increasing the chances of it getting discovered and sold from the huge selection of formal shirts that we already have. It's one of the possible many use-cases where we are using "Sense" as a kind of micro-messaging platform wherein the messages are getting published in real-time in an automated way driven by users' taste and current intent in general.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Divya Alok)

item.title: Visibility Part 1 - Product Ranking
item.description:
What is visibility?

Product discovery is an essential step in the journey of any e-commerce transaction. What gets seen is what gets sold; tougher the discovery of a product, lower is the sales potential. In our scenario product discovery is primarily achieved by
  • User driven actions through top-navigation pages, "search queries" on search bar, filtering and sorting.
  • Content interactions (on website) : Banner, look good, inline content, recommendations, breadcrumb, recently viewed etc.
  • Content interactions (off website) : Affiliates, google ads, remarketing, youtube, facebook, seo.
Visibility is just an outcome of any of the above mentioned product discovery led activity that a user does.

How is it measured?

Simply put, visibility can be defined as the number of eyeballs a product got through listing pages. Mathematically that translates to the sum total of listings happened for a product on any listing page across all visits. e.g. a visit to T-shirts list page will result in each product listed on the page getting counted as a "single list view". Summed over all visits for a day, we get the day total of list view or visibility for that product.

How is product ranking related to visibility?

Product ranking is one of the key influencer in overall aisle organisation and hence directly impacts visibility of a product on the website. In short, product rank of a product is a "score" which determines it's importance when compared with another product. e.g. if on a list page (also called storefront) there are two styles to be displayed (aisle organisation), the product with a higher score is put before the lower score product. Generally speaking, higher the score better the chances of discovery leading to better visibility.

Product ranking algorithm considerations

The product ranking algorithm takes into account various factors to arrive at "the final score". Some of these considerations are velocity of sale, actual sale, margin, availability, list conversion, etc. Majority of the factors are a proxy to what customers' likes and dislikes are and only some are business objective driven. To accommodate parameters (like sale velocity) which are sensitive to day's proceedings, the product rankings are refreshed thrice a day. Also, some of these parameter levers are exposed to business users (to override) as well for them to adapt to changes happening during the day.

Visibility - A limited resource

Visibility is an outcome of varied complex interactions that a visitor goes through on the website. The product ranking which influences visibility in a major way not only follows customer demand patterns but considers broader business goals as well. On a side note, noticeable dips in revenue were observed when non-proven products were artificially pushed on top.

Visibility is a limited resource; gives great returns when carefully spent!
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Divya Alok)

item.title: Introduction to Data Sciences blog
item.description:
I welcome you all to Data Sciences blog: "Sartorial Science” - a medium for socialising and democratising insights uncovered from data hopefully enabling all of us to collaborate effectively towards better decision making.

Needless to say, "Data Drives Decisions" is deeply rooted at Myntra and we continue to evolve that culture through diverse and sophisticated applications of data to achieve our business goals. Data Sciences is just another force multiplier in this direction. I sincerely believe that translating vast amounts of data into actionable insights via tools and algorithms has enormous potential. It enables us to reach up higher to not-so low hanging yet hopefully tasteful fruits. 

As data grows exponentially, the challenge cum opportunity for data sciences is to intelligently condense data; we strive to create rich abstractions of data in the hope of unlocking valuable insights which we did not have access to before. An equally important activity is to align data along business contexts ensuring a more meaningful discovery process leading to seamless integration of insights into our decision making process. 

The goal for this blog is to stimulate inquiry into data and trigger fruitful discussions helping translate deep insights into strategic use cases. I hope to have such discussions.

Deepak Warrier, VP Analytics & Data Science
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Deepak Warrier)

item.title: Understanding Brand Positioning
item.description:
How do consumers perceive brands? What is our brand positioning and what can we do about it?These questions are of interest to marketing and branding professionals, merchandisers, category planners.

Given the strategic importance of these concerns, it makes good sense to develop an understanding of these questions through the consumer lens, without resorting to any sampling which a typical 'offline survey' requires! The 'data exhaust' (clicks, purchases, likes etc.) that our customers and visitors leave, has valuable insights to offer on these questions.

In this post, we want to talk about the concept of Brand Entropy, which attempts to capture the users perception of brand and how they place it with others. Entropy is quite close to the notion of statistical variance that we often encounter in case of normal 'bell' curves.In this context, brand entropy quantifies the variance in choices or substitutions around a brand. Specifically, higher the entropy for a brand implies that users typically substitute it with other brands. Whereas, lower entropy points to a stronger brand preference or niche styling unique to a brand.

Having a quantifiable metric to compare brands could enable a structured approach to brand assortment problems around breadth and width optimization. For example, if the brand entropy is low with high demand, we should go deep and maybe even go exclusive.

We have initiated discussions around these extensions with category/merchandising teams.

How do we compute Brand Entropy?

We essentially look at the customer browse behavior in terms of the banners they click, pages & shops they like to browse, products they view and purchase. We consider the string of products browsed by a user in a session and infer the brand choices. We algorithmically sift through millions of user sessions spanning months and aggregate choice patterns. By removing noise and checking for statistical strength, we zero in on dominant patterns.

Brand Entropy then is just a matter of computing variance of patterns around the chosen brand.

Examples of Brand Entropy

Shown below are brand dominance seen around Vero Moda and Femella. It is quite clear that variability of user choice aroud Femella is much high compared to Vero Moda. Vero Moda shows strong brand preference while Femella is perceived similar to many other brands. The colour/size in the charts indexes the brand strength.This translates to low Brand Entropy value for Vero Moda and a higher value for Femella.





Similarly, in Formal Shoes Ruosh has much lower brand entropy compared to Franco Leone.



Comparing entropy values across brands in a category

We can now look at the entropy values across a snapshot of brands within a category. Below are the results for two categories - Kurtas Women and Dresses.





Interestingly, the above charts re-affirms some of our shared beliefs:

1) More established brands(Mango, UCB, Avirate, Biba, W etc.) in general have lower entropy values pointing to stronger brand equity

2) Low entropy values could also be a result of niche styling that a brand provides which is not replicated in other brands. Kook n Keech Disney for instance has lower value(0.159) since it offers a niche in comic character print dresses.

Men are more brand conscious than women

Here's the fun part: If we abstract the entropy concept at the gender level and compare across categories, we observe that women categories have considerably higher avg entropy.

It's becomes a proof point of what we intuitively understand - men being more brand focused than women! Almost all green and big circles belong to women categories in the chart below.




We'll be developing this idea further and will be glad to have your inputs.
item.author: noreply@blogger.com (Devashish Mittal)
